title: Geography and Gender: understanding the rising number of women on incapacity benefits.
abstractText: The number of women claiming incapacity benefits has been rising steadily for more than twenty years and is now nearly 1.1 million. Conventional explanations for the rising number of men claiming incapacity benefits have focused on the impact of declining manual job opportunities, particularly in older industrial areas where recipients of these benefits are over-represented. It is not obvious that the same explanations can be applied to women, for whom there have been rising job opportunities over a long period, even in most of Britainâ€™s less prosperous areas. For women, factors such as increased eligibility for benefits, increased ill-health due to work-life balance issues, changing household structures, changing gender divisions of labour and declining earnings of male partners may be important.
